artist: Artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Publisher: Sanoya Kihei
catalogue_raissonne: Ukiyo-e shūka 14 (1981), Hiroshige list, p. 236, horizontal chūban #24.43
creditline: Bequest of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription: 乗り合いのちいが雀のはなしにはやき蛤も舌をかくせり　楳の門鬼丸 {Noriai no chii ga suzume no hanashi ni hayaki hamaguri mo shita o kakuseri, Umenomon Kigan} (The varied statuses on the ferry—according to the sparrow, the roasted clams, too, hide their tongues, Umenomon Kigan)
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Fifty-three Stations along the Tōkaidō (Tōkaidō gojūsan tsugi 東海道五十三次), also known as the Kyōka Tōkaidō
text: On the left is a restaurant that, according to the two white signs, offers grilled clams (yaki hamaguri) as its specialty. The sign above the seated porter dressed in a loincloth is a “product placement” for the face powder Senjōko, sold at Kyobashi in Edo, a business that probably underwrote parts of the publication costs of this print.
title: Kuwana: View of the Tomita Post Station
